Description: Emanuel Leutze was born in the town of Schwäbisch Gmünd in the state of Württemberg in southern Germany. His family immigrated to the United States while he was a child, living first in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, before settling in Fredericksburg, Virginia. In 1840, sales of his early work enabled Leutze to study at Düsseldorf and then Munich. Leutze returned to America in 1851 on the occasion of the exhibition of what was to be his most popular work, Washington Crossing the Delaware (Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York). It is not known if this drawing of two women in classical dress relates to a specific painting by Leutze, but he used the pose, which derives from antique statuary, in several other compositions.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: American Artists Abroad: Works from the Permanent Collection
Exhibitions.Textblock: American Artists Abroad: Works from the Permanent Collection . The Walters Art Museum, Baltimore. 2014.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: German Drawings from the Walters Collection
Exhibitions.Textblock: German Drawings from the Walters Collection. The Walters Art Museum, Baltimore. 2010-2011.

Provenance: William T. Walters, Baltimore [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; Henry Walters, Baltimore, 1894, by inheritance; Walters Art Museum, 1931, by bequest.
Title: Woman Weeping at the Feet of Another
